title: Cobus Reinach
text:
Jacobus Meyer Reinach (born 7 February 1990) is a <a href="South%20African%20people">South African</a> professional <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player who plays for the <a href="Top%2014">Top 14</a> side <a href="Montpellier%20H%C3%A9rault%20Rugby">Montpellier</a> and <a href="South%20Africa%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">South Africa</a>. His playing position is <a href="Scrum-half%20%28rugby%20union%29">scrum-half</a> and he is the son of former Springbok <a href="Wing%20%28rugby%20union%29">winger</a> <a href="Jaco%20Reinach">Jaco Reinach</a>., He was the member of the victorious Springbok team at the <a href="2019%20Rugby%20World%20Cup">2019 Rugby World Cup</a> in Japan,Yokohama.
Early career.
Born and raised in <a href="Bloemfontein">Bloemfontein</a>, Reinach attended the famous rugby school <a href="Grey%20College%2C%20Bloemfontein">Grey College</a>. He initially played age-level rugby for the Free State, before heading to <a href="Durban">Durban</a> in 2009 to link up with the Sharks.
Club career.
His first forays into senior rugby came with the Sharks XV in the <a href="Vodacom%20Cup">Vodacom Cup</a>. During the <a href="2011%20Vodacom%20Cup">2011</a> and <a href="2012%20Vodacom%20Cup">2012 Vodacom Cup</a> competitions he made 17 appearances and scored 3 tries. His good performances at that level saw him promoted to the Sharks Currie Cup squad. He earned his first 2 Currie Cup caps during the <a href="2011%20Currie%20Cup%20Premier%20Division">2011 season</a> and over the following 2 campaigns he rotated with the more experienced <a href="Charl%20McLeod">Charl McLeod</a> for the starting role in the number 9 jersey. He was a Currie Cup winner in <a href="2013%20Currie%20Cup%20Premier%20Division">2013</a> and a runner up in <a href="2012%20Currie%20Cup%20Premier%20Division">2012</a> with both matched being played against . Following McLeod's departure to <a href="FC%20Grenoble">Grenoble</a> at the conclusion of the <a href="2014%20Super%20Rugby%20season">2014 Super Rugby season</a>, Reinach was left as the undisputed first-choice scrum half for the Sharks.
At Super Rugby level, Reinach debuted during the <a href="2012%20Super%20Rugby%20season">2012 Super Rugby season</a> however, he only made one appearance which amounted to 1 minute of game-time. His performances in tandem with Charl McLeod during the 2012 Currie Cup saw him see much more regular action in <a href="2013%20Super%20Rugby%20season">2013</a> and the two continued their rotation. 2014 saw him become much more of a regular starter and indeed despite missing 4 matches due to injury, Reinach started all 12 of the regular season matches he was available for and scored 6 tries including a memorable effort in the Sharks first ever win away to the in <a href="Christchurch">Christchurch</a>.
On 27 February 2017, it was announced that Reinach would link up with English club <a href="Northampton%20Saints">Northampton Saints</a> in the <a href="English%20Premiership%20%28rugby%20union%29">Aviva Premiership</a> from the 2017/18 season.
On 12 June 2020, Reinach officially joined <a href="Montpellier%20H%C3%A9rault%20Rugby">Montpellier</a> in the <a href="Top%2014">Top 14</a> ahead of the 2020–21 season after leaving Northampton
International career.
Although his father had twice been selected for South African Schools, Reinach never represented his country at any age-group level. However, this did not stop him from making the full Springbok side at the age of only 24. He was called up to the Springbok squad for the <a href="2014%20Rugby%20Championship">2014 Rugby Championship</a> due to the absence of the injured <a href="Fourie%20du%20Preez">Fourie du Preez</a> and when another experienced number 9 in <a href="Ruan%20Pienaar">Ruan Pienaar</a> went down injured during the Boks tour of Australasia, Reinach was promoted to back-up scrum-half for the remaining two home games of the competition against and . Reinach debuted as a second-half replacement for <a href="Francois%20Hougaard">Francois Hougaard</a> in South Africa's 28–10 win over Australia in <a href="Cape%20Town">Cape Town</a> on 27 September 2014 and played a big role in the Boks bonus point try scored by <a href="Jean%20de%20Villiers">Jean de Villiers</a> in the final minute. He got his second taste of international rugby a week later and was again on the winning side as his team earned their first win over the All Blacks since 2011. On 8 October 2019 Reinach scored a <a href="Hat-trick%23Rugby%20football">hat-trick</a> in a 66–7 win over <a href="Canada%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Canada</a> at the <a href="2019%20Rugby%20World%20Cup">2019 Rugby World Cup</a>, the fastest hat-trick in Rugby World Cup History. South Africa went on to win the tournament, defeating <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">England</a> in the final.
